title: Were there ever Irish knights? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suspect that by “Irish” knights, you mean knights within Gaelic Irish culture? Well, the answer to that is no. The closest equivalent to knights would be the armed retainers the Gaelic chiefs would have at their disposal, the lucht tighe (“household troops”). These were generally horsemen, well-armed, and could consist of sub-chiefs, mercenaries, or some of the landless, aristocratic soldiers that wandered Ireland selling their swords to the highest bidder. The lucht tighe would be the elite of the troops at the Gaelic chief’s disposal, and would generally be used to spearhead any military operations, whether it be conventional campaigns or, far more commonly, cattle-raids and the ilk. In 1397 a Catalan pilgrim to Lough Derg observed some of the lucht tighe of a chieftain of the O’Neill family. He describes them as such: “They ride without a saddle on a cushion and each wears a cloak according to his rank. They are armed with coats of mail, and round iron helmets like the Moors and Saracens. Some of them are like the Bernese. They have swords and very long knives and long lances.”  Gaelic horsemen during the 1590’s from The Images of Irelande, a contemporary woodcut by John Derrick

There were the Knights of Glin (Black Knight) who were Fitzgeralds as were the Knights of Kerry (Green Knight) and the White Knight (Fitzgibbon). These were orders of chivalry given to Gaelicised families though they weren’t native Irish. Some Irish were knighted and passed their titles down. If you mean where there Irish heavily armoured cavalry, not enough to form large companies of men at arms but I suspect the nobility if they had the means would arm themselves with the best equipment that they could
